items.item_text: 5:00 p.m. - Call Meeting to Order at the District Board Room, 4750 San Felipe Road, San Jose, CA 95135
items.item_text_raw: 1. 5:00 p.m. - Call Meeting to Order at the District Board Room, 4750 San Felipe Road, San Jose, CA 95135

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the following Management Personnel Actions:
	 
1.  Employment
Employment of Facilities Manager for SJCC.
Employment of METAS Project Director for SJCC.
	 
2.  Contract Change
Reducing the FTE of the Director of @One Project for EVC from 100% to 60% effective 07/01/11 to 01/31/12. 
	 
3.  Temporary Change of Status
The change of Nursing Instructor to Interim Dean of Nursing and Allied Health for EVC effective 06/27/11 to 05/25/12.
	 
The Director of Financial Aid for SJCC will receive a temporary increase of 5% for his expanded role overseeing the A&R department, effective 07/01/11 to 12/31/11.
	 
The Dean of Business and Technology for SJCC will receive a temporary increase to Step 32/4 for his expanded role overseeing the Applied Sciences department, effective 01/01/11 to 06/30/11.
	 
4.  Separation/Termination
The Dean of Math, Science and Engineering for EVC resigned effective 08/02/11.

items.item_details:
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the Faculty Association AFT 157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.20 submission and recommendation: 
Article 9.20 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all Districts assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.   
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.20 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.
	 
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the Faculty Association AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District  Article 15.2.1 submission and recommendation:
	 
Article 15.2.1 Full-time unit members' overload assignment  for compensation and/or overload banking shall be based on a separate contract which shall normally be limited to 6 (six) units or 40% of a full load. Exceptions to this maximum overload shall be negotiated with the Faculty Association.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 15.2.1 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.. .

items.item_details:
The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
	 
.
Position Establishment  
The establishment of the positions: Assistant Head Coach and Assistant Head Coach/Off-Season for Athletics effective 08/10/11.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. District Policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (current bid limit is $78,900) should have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes the purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $750, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of May 10, 2011 through July 9, 2011 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details: The Board of Trustees adopted the District's operating budget at its special meeting on September 28, 2010.  As required by Board Policy 6250, subsequent budget transfers and revisions must be approved by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the resolution authorizing the 2010-2011 budget transfers and revisions of funds within expenditure accounts, authorizing the appropriation of the receipt of unanticipated revenues in certain programs, and authorizing the reversal of appropriations in certain programs due to the non-receipt of program revenues.
items.item_text: District Budget Transfers and Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 8. District Budget Transfers and Revisions

items.item_details:
The Associated Students of Evergreen Valley College (ASEVC) approved their 2011-2012 budget on Monday, June 27, 2011. Compared to the previous two years, this budget has been reduced by nearly $50,000. This reduction is due to inaccurate budget reports provided in previous years where funds in reserves were included in the budget as income. 
	 
Although the ASEVC are aware that further withdrawing funds from reserves is not a sound budgetary practice, they have decided to decrease the budget by $50,000 rather than drastically cutting it by half. This will permit the ASEVC to continue to fund programs that augment financial assistance to low-income EVC students at a reduced level. The plan is to gradually decrease the expenses this year so that it does not adversely affect students that have become dependent on programs such as the Book Voucher Program and Emergency Student Grant. The goal is to inform the EVC student body of changes to funding this year and to attain a balanced budget by the 2012-13 fiscal year.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Evergreen Valley College Associated Students budget for 2011-12.
items.item_text: Evergreen Valley College Associated Students 2011-12 Budget
items.item_text_raw: 9. Evergreen Valley College Associated Students 2011-12 Budget

items.item_details:
By contracting with the State Chancellor's Office, the District may recover outstanding student debts owed such as enrollment fees and library fines.  Under the program, the State Chancellor's Office requests the Franchise Tax Board to offset (deduct) the amount owed to the District from the student's personal state income tax refund, lottery winnings, or other state refund.  The Franchise Tax Board remits any amounts offset to the State Chancellor's Office, which then authorizes the State Controller to disburse the offset amount, less a 25% administrative fee, to the District.
	 
The COTOP is one of a multi-pronged approach to recover outstanding student debts.  The District sends emails to students throughout the term advising of their outstanding balance and providing options to satisfy their outstanding balance.  Upon completion of the term, students who still have an outstanding balance despite receiving emails during the term are sent a letter advising that the balance remains outstanding, that a hold remains on their account, the options available to them to satisfy their outstanding balance, and that failure to satisfy the outstanding debt within 30 days may result in their account being referred to an external collection agency.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the contract with the State Chancellor's Office for the District to participate in the 2012 Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP).
items.item_text: Agreement - 2012 State Controller's Office Tax Offset Program
items.item_text_raw: 10. Agreement - 2012 State Controller's Office Tax Offset Program

items.item_details:
The San Jose Evergreen Community College District's Police Department was awarded $1,500 in grant funds to supplement its Community Emergency Response Training (CERT) Initiative.  The majority of the funds will be used to provide training for staff and faculty to become CERT members, as well as supply emergency equipment to individual CERT members in their capacity as building monitors, zone leaders, and assignees to the District's Emergency Operations Center.
	 
The grant is funded through the continued partnership between the California Community College Chancellor's Office and the California Emergency Management Agency and is being awarded to 25 community college districts for a total of $39,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept and appropriate grant funds in the amount of $1,500 awarded to the San Jose Evergreen Community College District's Police Department

items.item_details:
Acceptance of Grant Funds -   Aurora Project Community Colleges Component of the UC Science and Mathematics Initiative (CalTeach)
	 
This funding supports SJCC students who are taking the Education 14 & 15 -Field Experience in Math & Science. These courses are designed to encourage students to consider a career in teaching Mathematics or Science in the K-12 system by providing field experiences in math and science instruction at local middle or high schools in addition to classroom pedagogical instruction in math and science education.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept grant funds from the Aurora Project Community Colleges Component of the UC Science and Mathematics Initiative (CalTeach)

items.item_details:
San Jose City College wishes to establish an MOU to partner with Saint Elizabeth’s Day Home, a California nonprofit charitable public benefit corporation (hereinafter “Sub-Contractor”). San Jose City College has found the Sub-Contractor to be able to meet the needs of the Child Development Division, California Department of Education (CDE) for state child development program services for both Toddler and Preschool care. Also, St. Elizabeth’s Day Home has prior experience as a sub-contractor operating programs funded by the Child Development Division, California Department of Education.
	 
As the certified CDD contractor, SJCC will continue to meet the condition of its contract with the California Department of Education, Child Development Division and to adhere to the Funding Terms and Conditions (FT&C). San Jose City College has reviewed various potential subcontractors and found St. Elizabeth’s Day Home to be the most qualified to perform services under this contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the contract attached in order to sub-contract the State Department of Education Grants to St. Elizabethâs Day Home. Contractor will receive $226,576 of CDE funding, campus will retain $9,440 for indirect costs.
items.item_text: Sub-Contract for Child Development Center California Dept of Education Child Care Contracts
items.item_text_raw: 14. Sub-Contract for Child Development Center California Dept of Education Child Care Contracts

items.item_details:
Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide a wide variety of job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers.   Since 2005, the Workforce Institute has delivered over 20,000 hours of job readiness (242,000 attendees) workshops at multiple locations including the three primary work2future One-Stops (Campbell, Gilroy and San Jose).  Since 2008, the Workforce Institute has provided online training to over 1,500 job seekers in an effort to equip them with the skills (high level programming, project management, accounting, entrepreneurship, etc.) they need to market themselves in this tight economic market.
 
For program year 2011-2012, work2future has awarded Workforce Institute $1,053,300 for continuing services.
 
In an effort to meet the diverse needs of Santa Clara County job seekers, Workforce Institute is subcontracting with the following entities:
 
1. Center for Training and Careers (CTC) -- Job Readiness Workshops ($123,000)
2. Gavilan College -- English/Spanish Job Readiness Workshops at the Gilroy One-Stop ($19,000)
3. Career Advancement Solutions (CAS) -- Job Readiness Workshops ($45,000)
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2011-2012 WIA Workshop Grant.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute - WIA work2future Workshop Contract
items.item_text_raw: 15. Workforce Institute - WIA work2future Workshop Contract

items.item_details: Since 2005, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA Youth intensive services and is being funded to continue those services for the 2011-12 program year.  Services include eligibility determination, assessment, counseling/case management, job development/placement services, for youth ages 17-21, who are low income with at least one barrier to obtaining employment. This program offers the WorkKeys Career Readiness Certificate, National Retail Federation's Customer Service Training and a choice of enrollment into the San Jose Promise Program, Pathways to Teaching, Hospitality Training or Building Systems Maintenance Technician Training. Upon completion of training, participants receive one-on-one job placement assistance. Incentives and supportive services are offered throughout the program to ensure that the participants finish the program. Contract funding for the 2011-2012 Program Year is $486,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2011-2012 WIA Older Youth Contract.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute - WIA work2future Older Youth Contract
items.item_text_raw: 16. Workforce Institute - WIA work2future Older Youth Contract

items.item_details: Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA intensive services and is being funded to continue those services for the 2011-12 program year.  Services include assessment and job development/placement services for Adults and Dislocated Workers that are 18 or older that have been affected by the downturn in the economy. Program services are also delivered to employers in Santa Clara County. These services include placement assistance, job fair participation, and Career Readiness Certificate test proctoring. These services are provided at the San Jose One Stop, the Campbell One Stop and the Gilroy One Stop.  Contract funding for the 2011-2012 Program Year is $385,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2011-2012 WIA Adult Program Contract.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute WIA Adult Program Contract
items.item_text_raw: 17. Workforce Institute WIA Adult Program Contract

items.item_details:
In September 2010, the Workforce Institute in collaboration with the Santa Clara and San Benito Counties Building Trades Council (BTC), the National Labor College, and San José City College submitted a final application to obtain funding for the development of a construction management program.  The Congressionally-Directed grant was officially awarded to the Institute on September 24, 2010 for $368,000. The Board of Trustees approved the grant at the November 9th, 2010 Board meeting.
 
In the original contract, Mark Browne was identified in the subcontractor line item to receive $93,000 to provide project consulting activities including assisting with the development of curriculum and related components (labs, capstone project, etc.) for the BA in Construction Management Program of Study, as well as related certificates of study including the coordination of construction industry input and approval, and submission in writing according to NLC format and in coordination with their faculty approval. These activities necessitated travel to the National Labor College in Maryland, and up to $6,000 was allocated in the budget for travel but was inadvertently not included in the original independent contractor agreement.  The independent contractor agreement has been revised to reflect the increase of $5,150 for travel.  No budget re-alignment was required.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Independent Contractor Agreement for the California Construction College Grant.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute - California Construction College Grant/Revision of Independent Contractor Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 18. Workforce Institute - California Construction College Grant/Revision of Independent Contractor Agreement

items.item_details: At the June 14, 2011 meeting, the Board of Trustees approved the hiring of the Vice President, Administrative Services, at Evergreen Valley College. Because this position was not listed in the district's 2010 version of the Conflict of Interest Code, we have added this position and also changed the name of the Vice President, Instruction position to Vice President, Academic Affairs. After the Board approves the revised code, it will be forwarded to the Santa Clara County Office to be approved by the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors.
